mainmatter.p: A space X has no separation iff its only clopen subsets are the trivial ones.

( \Rightarrow ) Suppose space X has no separation and let F \subseteq X be a clopen. Suppose, towards a contradiction, that F is a nontrivial subset i.e. it is neither \empty nor X. Denote by F^{-1} the complement of F in X. The set F^{-1} must be clopen and disjoint from F by definition. Because F \neq X, it must exclude some point x \in X, which must be contained by F^{-1} by construction. This means F^{-1} is nonempty. Therefore, the pair (F, F^{-1}) is a separation of the space X: X = F \cup F^{-1}, both F and F^{-1} are nonempty, and they are disjoint from each other. This contradicts the assumption X has no separation.

( \Leftarrow ) Suppose the only clopen subsets of space X are the trivial ones i.e. \empty and X. Suppose X had a separation (U, V). Then V must be the complement of U in X. This means that it must be closed, by virtue of being the complement of an open U. Also, the open U must be closed too since it is itself the complement of the open V. As both U and V are both nonempty, they both cannot be either \empty or X. This means they are both nontrivial clopens.

There are different definitions of connectedness that are classicaly equivalent.
The standard definition is the one that says a space is connected if no separation for it exists. 1 200 Definition axt-000E axt-000E.xml 2023 9 4 Connected space (set-theoretic)
A topological space X is called connected if there does not exist a pair U, V \in \mathcal{O} (X) of disjoint and nonempty open sets such that X = U \cup V.
Such a pair (U, V) is called a separation of the space X.
Another one is the nonexistence of nontrivial clopen sets. 2 201 Definition axt-000F axt-000F.xml 2023 9 4 Connected space (clopen)
A topological space X is connected if for any subset A \subseteq X, if A is clopen then A is either the empty set \emptyset or the entire set X. These two definitions are classically equivalent. 3 202 Theorem axt-000H axt-000H.xml 2023 9 4 Ayberk Tosun
